title: Julian Dehne
text:
Dehne J., Strickroth S., & Lucke U. (2020): FL-Trail: digitally supporting group-based inquiry learning. In: Zender R., Ifenthaler D., Leonhardt T., & Schumacher C. (Eds.): DELFI 2020 - Die 18. Fachtagung Bildungstechnologien der Gesellschaft für Informatik e.V. Bonn: Gesellschaft für Informatik e.V. (pp. 319-330).
Dehne Julian, Knoth Alexander, & Lucke Ulrike (2019): Strengthening the study entry phase research-based learning and the use of digital media. In: Gabi Reinmann, Eileen Lübcke, and Anna Heudorfer (eds.): Research-based learning in the study entry phase. Wiesbaden: Springer Fachmedien Wiesbaden.
Dehne Julian, Schiefner-Rohs Mandy, & Lucke Ulrike (2017): Digital media and research-oriented teaching and learning-empirical insights into projects and teaching concepts. In: Proceedings of the 25th Annual Meeting of the Society for Media in Science (GMW), September 5-8, 2017, Chemnitz, Germany: Waxmann. (Best Paper Award)
Dehne Julian, Wiepke Axel, & Lucke Ulrike (2017): Evaluating e-learning - A comment on “Media will never influence learning”. In: Christoph Igel, Carsten Ullrich, and Wessner Martin (eds.): Bildungsräume2017: Gesellschaft für Informatik Bonn, pp. 167-177.





Dehne Julian, & Lucke Ulrike (2015): An infrastructure for cross-platform competence-based assessment. In: Facing the Challenges of Assessing 21st Century Skills in the Newly Emerging Educational Ecosystems (ECTEL), Toledo, pp. 29-38.
Dehne Julian, & Nguyen Thi (2017): Defining consistency in higher education. EARLI 2017, Tampere, August 2017. (Poster).
Dehne Julian, Nguyen Thi, & Lübcke Eileen (2017): A model of media-supported inquiry-based learning. EARLI 2017, Tampere, August 2017. (Poster).
Dehne Julian, Nguyen Thi, & Lucke Ulrike (2016): Bridging the interinstitutional gap - Tracing lifelong skill evolution. In: The Higher Education Conference (HEC). (Presentation).
Zender Raphael, Dehne Julian, Geßner Hendrik, & Lucke Ulrike (2013): RouteMe - Routing in ad hoc networks as a pervasive learning game. In: i-com12(1), pp.45-52.
Paaßen B., & Dehne J. (2022): A conceptual graph-based model of creativity in learning. In: Frontiers in Education, (p. 851). Frontiers.





Dehne J., & Gold V. (2024, under review): Comparing the Effectiveness of Different User Moderation Strategies for Deliberation on Twitter. In: Journal of Political Communication.
Dehne J., & Gold V. (2024, under review): Strategies for Deliberative Moderation in Social Media. In: Journal of Deliberative Democracy.

title: Julian Dehne
text: While in Potsdam, I developed a pioneering concept on the persistence of learning outcomes and its applications. However, encountering challenges in mainstreaming the COMPBASE (not public) platform for testing, I redirected my thesis toward Inquiry-Based Learning, leading to the creation of the FL-Trail tool that supports student-centered learning.

title: Research
text:
Educational technologies
Algorithms in the educational sector
Modeling of learning processes
Learning analytics and creativity research
Higher education didactics
Curriculum research





Delaboration Laboratory: University of Göttingen, 2021 – Present
Detecting and Supporting Creativity Online: Humboldt University Berlin, 2020 – 2021
Research Orientation in the Study Entrance Phase: University of Potsdam, 2015 - 2020
E-Learning in Study Areas: University of Potsdam, 2012 – 2015




“Possibilities and Limitations of Media Support for Inquiry-Based Learning”: Explores the use of computer technology to support inquiry-based learning in higher education. Read more

title: About
text: About this site

title: Julian Dehne
text:
Hello! I am Julian Dehne!
After completing a BA in European Studies at the University of Passau, I sought to enhance my background with expertise in Computer Science. The dual subject teacher program in Brandenburg and Berlin uniquely offered a combination of Political Science and Computer Science, which aligned perfectly with my interests. During my stay at the University of Potsdam, I had the privilege of working under Professor Ulrike Lucke, a leading figure in e-learning research in Germany.
Following my PhD, I briefly joined Humboldt University in Berlin, where I co-authored one of the first conceptual papers on fostering creativity through e-learning. Subsequently, I decided to return to my roots in the social sciences, accepting a PostDoc position at the University of Göttingen in the CSS field. Here, our team has been developing an innovative chatbot designed to facilitate deliberation on social media, which is nearing operational functionality.

Email: julian.dehne@gmail.com
Website: ResearchGate Profile
Orcid: 0000-0001-9265-9619

M.S. in Computer Science and Political Science: University of Potsdam, 19.09.2009 - 13.10.2014
B.A. in European Studies: University of Passau, 15.04.2008 - 19.09.2009





Research Associate: University of Göttingen, 31.08.2021 – 31.04.2024
Research Associate: Humboldt University of Berlin, 31.08.2020 - 31.01.2021
Research Assistant: University of Potsdam, 26.10.2014 - 31.08.2020
Teacher: Berlin, 01.08.2013 - 15.04.2014
Intern: International Organization for Migration, 15.01.2009 - 15.04.2009





English: Fluent (TOEFL CBS 283/300)
French: Advanced (University of Geneva Certificate)
Spanish: Advanced (Maccu Piccu Spanish School Certificate)
Polish: A1 (Unicert)
Latin: “Großes Latinum”
Ancient Greek: Graecum





Programming Languages: Java, JavaScript, Scala, Prolog, Python
Databases: SQL derivatives, Neo4j, RDF
Statistical Software: Stata, Octave, R, Python
